Chapter 7 VC theory In Chapter 6 we defined the shatter coefficient as the number of times we can intersect \(\{X_1,...,X_n\}\in\mathcal{X}\) with subsets \(A\) of \(\mathcal{X}\) that belong to the family \(\mathcal{A}\), in particular: \[ \begin{equation} \begin{aligned} && S(X_1^n,\mathcal{A})&= \left|\{A\cup\{X_1,...,X_n\}:A\in\mathcal{A}\} \right| \\ \end{aligned} \tag{7.1} \end{equation} \] We further defined: \[ \begin{equation} \begin{aligned} && S_{\mathcal{A}}(n)&=\max_{X_1,...,X_n}S(X_1^n,\mathcal{A}) \\ \end{aligned} \tag{7.2} \end{equation} \] Clearly, we have that \(S(X_1^n,\mathcal{A})\le2^n\), where \(2^n\) is simply the total number of subsets of \(n\) points: each point can either be in a given subset or not. Definition 7.1 If \(S(X_1^n,\mathcal{A})=2^n\), then we say that the class \(\mathcal{A}\) shatters \(\{X_1,...,X_n\}\). Suppose the class \(\mathcal{A}\) shatter the \(n\) points. This means that for each possible subset, we can find a set in \(\mathcal{A}\) that can be intersected with the subset. In the context of our initial problem \(\mathbb{E} \max_{A\in\mathcal{A}} |P_n(A)-P(A)|\) and the VC theorem, this means we are in trouble: we expect that overfitting will occur. 7.1 VC dimension Definition 7.2 Let \(\mathcal{A}\) be a class if sets. The the VC dimension of \(\mathcal{A}\) is the largest integer such that \(S_{\mathcal{A}}(V)=2^V\). In other words, \(V\) is the size of the largest set of points that can be shattered by \(\mathcal{A}\). If \(S_{\mathcal{A}}(n)=2^n\) for all \(n\), then \(V=\infty\)
